title: Can blasting silence on a speaker make a room quiet? - Quora

response.answer_text: In spite of the Simon and Garfunkel song, there is no such thing as the sound of silence. Zero sound energy is zero sound energy. You could multiply silence by multiples of a million, but a million times zero still equals zero. That said, if you have a microphone and specialized software, you can essentially invert the phase of a waveform and as long as it's the same amplitude, this will essentially cancel out the previous noise. This is, in a dramatically over simplified way of describing it, how noise cancelling headphones work. They work best with repetitive, steady sounds in the same frequency and amplitude, such as traffic or jet engine noise. They don't work as well with occasional sounds like people talking or somebody banging on something with a hammer.

Sound is vibration in the air at an audible frequency or frequencies. Silence means no audible vibrations or no sound. Since sound is a vibration there is no way to blast silence. The phrase ”blasting silence” is meaningless. You can make a small area silent by inverting the ambient sound and sending it out at the same level. That's how noise-canceling headsets work. That's not the same as ”blasting silence”.

Silence is the absence of sound; you cannot generate sound to create it (unless you’re using a generated sound to “cancel out” an exsiting sound) any more than you make a room completely dark by using a “special light bulb”.
